text: The Carboxyl-Terminal FKH Domain Is Not Required for Suppression of NF-kappaB Activation in T Cells

To define the requirements of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with respect to inhibition of NF-kappaB - dependent transcription , we utilized a mutant of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> lacking the FKH domain ( Figure 2A ) [ 16 ] , similar to the scurfy mutant <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> of mice , and a mutant <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein from a patient with IPEX [ 4 , 11 , 14 , 17 ] .

Unlike full-length <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which localizes almost exclusively to the nucleus and can bind in a sequence - specific manner to forkhead binding sites , the <extra_id_0> deltaFKH mutant <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> fails to localize to the nucleus and thus can not interact with promoter elements or nuclear proteins [ 16 ] .

text: Therefore , we utilized the <extra_id_0> deltaFKH mutant <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to determine whether nuclear localization ( or other function associated with the FKH domain ) of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was a prerequisite for inhibition of NF-kappaB activation .

Although <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interaction with NF-kappaB presumably takes place in the nucleus , it may also be possible for a cytoplasmic <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein to bind to NF-kappaB in the cytoplasm and prevent localization to the nucleus following an activation stimulus .

text: Overexpression of full-length <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but not of <extra_id_0> deltaFKH <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , was able to suppress activation of a cotransfected NF-kappaB reporter vector in HEK 293T cells ( Figure 2B ) .

text: These data appear to suggest that the carboxyl-terminal FKH domain is critically important for <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to down - regulate NF-kappaB - dependent transcription .

However , NF-kappaB activation was blocked to a similar extent by both full-length <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> deltaFKH <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in Jurkat T cells ( Figure 2C ) and primary human <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells ( Figure 2D ) .

Western blot analysis of NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression demonstrated that <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> deltaFKH <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> does not block NF-kappaB activation at the level of <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein expression ( Figure 2E ) .

text: These results are very interesting with respect to <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> function , because they suggest that the carboxyl-terminal FKH domain , and possibly nuclear localization , are dispensable for <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> function in T cell populations .
Alternative interpretations may include the possibility that the localization of <extra_id_0> deltaFKH <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> differ between epithelial cells and T cells .
In either case , these results suggest a cell type - specific mechanism of action for this <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutant .
